author: Western Morning News
title: Calais crisis could be behind surge in Brittany Ferry bookings...
text:
By Western Morning News | Posted: July 31, 2015 Calais crisis could be behind surge in Brittany Ferry bookings via Westcountry   
A surge in Brittany Ferry bookings could be down to the Calais crisis – and will see hundreds more people coming through Plymouth to reach Britain via the Westcountry this summer. 
Brittany Ferries, which runs daily crossings to Roscoff in France and weekly crossings to Spain’s Santander port from Millbay, saw July bookings increase by 12 per cent on last year. 
A spokesman for the firm said currently the August bookings are also running at 12 percent above last year – and are expected to rise further with last-minute bookings. 
They added: “We don’t know for sure, but it could well be that people are arranging their holidays and are watching the TV news and seeing these dramatic scenes. Related content Compensation call for losses due to Channel Tunnel chaos 
“The Foreign Office have put out advice for visiting France which includes people being urged to keep windows and doors locked as they go through Calais. 
“Warnings like that may have an effect on people who might feel they don’t want to go through that. 
“Those people who don’t usually travel through Plymouth, or who have not travelled with us before, hopefully they will continue to travel with us even when the Calais situation has been resolved.” 
Oliver Colvile, MP for Sutton Harbour and Devonport, welcomed the news, saying Plymouth needed to capitalise on the increased footfall into the city. 
He told The Herald: “I think this is very good news and we have got to make sure that we have events going on within the city so that people can actually do things. 
“I think Plymouth delivers really good value for money as far as people coming here to enjoy our city are concerned. 
“Plymouth also gives everybody a really warm welcome.” 
Recent reports have suggested thousands of migrants were encamped in Calais, as they attempted to board lorries on the French side of the Eurotunnel. 
On Monday night, there were reports that more than 2,000 migrants had attempted to storm the tunnel itself. 
The French port has also been besieged by protesting ferry workers, some of whom set light to hundreds of tyres laid across roads leading to the port, over possible job cuts. 
At the same time, French farmers, pursuing a separate dispute about prices, are blocking several towns and motorways in western France with tractors and trailers. 
Although the increase in bookings could be down to the Calais crisis, Tim Jones, chairman of Devon and Cornwall Business Council, also credited the increased footfall to a two-year campaign to improve Plymouth’s profile and to build on the city’s tourist attractions. 
He said: “The point behind this is that it is not just about traditional tourism; it’s about Plymouth’s quality of retail, leisure and food and drink offering and that now puts it on an international stage. 
“This is the result of a lot of hard work by Plymouth City Council and the destination and tourism marketing. I don’t see this as just a one-off – I expect to see it improving over time. 
“It is part of a long-term campaign to make sure that Plymouth punches above its weight, in particular to cement the relationship with near Europe, and Brittany Ferries are a key component for that.” 
The Foreign Office’s current travel advice has noted the industrial action by the farmers and ferry workers, as well as the disruption caused by the illegal migrants in and around Calais. 
Their advice states: “You should keep vehicle doors locked in slow moving traffic and secure your vehicle when it is left unattended.”
